According to a report by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF, the estimated cost to provide water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services in all healthcare facilities in the 46 least developed countries is around $1.3 billion per year.

The total amount of official development assistance (ODA) from donor countries, which is a major component of international aid, was approximately $161.2 billion in 2020, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

To find the percentage, we can use the following calculation:

\[
\text{Percentage} = \left( \frac{\text{Cost of WASH in healthcare facilities}}{\text{Total international aid}} \right) \times 100
\]

\[
\text{Percentage} = \left( \frac{1.3 \text{ billion USD}}{161.2 \text{ billion USD}} \right) \times 100 \approx 0.81\%
\]

So, the cost to install clean water and sanitation in all healthcare facilities in the 46 poorest countries is approximately 0.81% of the total international aid in 2020.
